name: Borage Oil
summary: A seed oil rich in gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), studied for its anti-inflammatory, dermatologic, and hormonal health benefits, with emerging evidence in mood and stress regulation.
description: Borage oil is derived from the seeds of Borago officinalis, a medicinal plant. It is one of the richest natural sources of gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), an omega-6 fatty acid that supports anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory pathways. Traditionally used for skin disorders such as eczema, rheumatoid arthritis, and premenstrual syndrome (PMS), borage oil has also been studied for cardiovascular and neurological support. Its role in psychiatry is emerging, particularly in adjunctive support for mood and stress regulation.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement, not FDA-approved for medical indications

off_label_uses: Adjunctive treatment for stress and mood dysregulation
contraindications: Liver disease (rare reports of hepatotoxic pyrrolizidine alkaloids in poorly processed oils)
monitoring_required: Liver function (if used long-term or in high doses)

items: PMS-related breast tenderness, irritability, and bloating

sections.text: Borage oil contains high levels of gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), which is converted into dihomo-γ-linolenic acid (DGLA). This leads to the production of anti-inflammatory prostaglandins and reduced synthesis of pro-inflammatory eicosanoids. These effects improve skin barrier function, reduce inflammation, and support hormonal balance. Preliminary research suggests GLA may also influence neuronal signaling and stress response.

adult.note: Divided doses with food recommended for best absorption.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; limited safety data
sections.geriatric: Similar dosing to adults; monitor for interactions and tolerability

sections.text: Improvements in skin and PMS symptoms may take 6–12 weeks of continuous use. Anti-inflammatory benefits build gradually over time.

serious: Rare hepatotoxicity from pyrrolizidine alkaloids if oil is not properly purified

other: Ensure supplements are certified PA-free to reduce risk of liver toxicity.
Avoid use in patients with active liver disease or significant hepatic impairment.

sections.pregnancy: Not recommended; insufficient data on safety
sections.lactation: Limited safety evidence; avoid unless supervised
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for polypharmacy and bleeding risk

sections.text: Not required; discontinuation may lead to gradual return of symptoms.

items: Borage oil contains the highest GLA concentration among seed oils, higher than evening primrose and black currant oil.
Choose certified PA-free borage oil to minimize hepatotoxicity risk.
May serve as an alternative for patients not responding to evening primrose or black currant oil supplementation.
